questions.explanation:

questions.text: An 8-year-old male child presented with a history of low-grade fever and migratory joint pains for the last 2 weeks. He also developed a skin lesion as shown below. The earliest valvular lesion in a case of acute rheumatic fever is:
questions.explanation:

Mitral regurgitation (MR) The image shows the characteristic erythema marginatum rash of acute rheumatic fever. It begins as pink macules that clear centrally, leaving a serpiginous, spreading edge. The rash is evanescent appearing and disappearing before the examiner's eyes. It occurs usually on the trunk, sometimes on the limbs but rarely on the face. The characteristic earliest valvular lesion is mitral regurgitation.

questions.text: A person with mitral regurgitation and atrial fibrillation was managed with a drug at a private clinic. He was later referred to a tertiary hospital with syncope without any neurological deficit. On examination, the person has a heart rate of 55 bpm. What is the most probable cause?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Digitalis toxicity All patients with mitral regurgitation have an increase in the size of the left atrium which predisposes to chronic atrial fibrillation . In these patients, digoxin is initiated for rate control . Since it causes prolongation of AV nodal block, bradycardia can occur in this case, leading to syncope . Digoxin can help in rate control in AF by sowing conduction through AV node-hence bradycardia can be a side effect as seen in this patient.

questions.text: You are seeing patient RJT, a 45-year-old previously healthy man, for a physical examination. This is his first time coming to a doctor in over 20 years. On examination, you auscultate a grade II diastolic murmur. He is asymptomatic, denying chest pain, dyspnea, edema, or any syncopal or pre-syncopal episodes. Examination reveals no other abnormalities, including normal carotid pulses, a nondisplaced point of maximal impulse on cardiac palpation, and clear lung fields. Electrocardiogram and chest x-ray are normal. What is the next best step for the evaluation of his murmur?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Echocardiogram The majority of heart murmurs are mid-systolic and soft grades I–II/VI). When such a murmur occurs in an asymptomatic child or young adult without other evidence of heart disease on clinical examination, it is usually benign and echocardiography generally is not required. In contrast, two-dimensional and Doppler echocardiography is indicated in patients with loud systolic murmurs (grades ≥III/VI), especially those that are holosystolic or late systolic, and in patients with diastolic or continuous murmurs.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options: A, B. Cardiac CT & MRI are not a first-line investigations for murmurs Option: C. Carotid ultrasound will not give us information on this murmur

questions.text: Mrs. Marisha, an 85-year-old former lawyer presents with several months of accelerating dyspnea on exertion and lower extremity edema. On examination, you note a laterally displaced point of maximal impulse and an S4 gallop. She has a III/IV systolic murmur at the base radiating to the carotid arteries. A transthoracic echocardiogram reveals a left ventricular ejection fraction of 25% with global hypokinesis. The calculated aortic valve area is 0.8 cm2 with a mean gradient of 25 mmHg. What is the next most reasonable step to determine whether Mrs. Marisha would benefit from aortic valve replacement?

options.label: A
options.text: Cardiac MRI to evaluate ventricular scar and aortic valve morphology

options.label: B
options.text: Cardiac positron emission tomography to determine ventricular viability

options.label: C
options.text: Coronary angiography to evaluate for the presence of obstructive coronary disease

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dobutamine stress echocardiography The question shows evidence of the clinical entity “low gradient, low flow aortic stenosis.” dobutamine stress will assess for ventricular viability (the ability to increase stroke volume by 20%, which is shown to predict outcomes after aortic valve replacement. Second, a s the ventricular contractility increases , it allows the clinician to differentiate between true, morphologic AS and the appearance of AS due to compromised ventricular function (termed pseudo-aortic stenosis). While the other options may aid in other facets of this patient’s management, none will allow the clinician to make this differentiation.

Highyeild:

Indications of stress echocardiography Known or suspected CAD. Assessment of myocardial viability. Assessment of dyspnea of possible cardiac origin. Pulmonary hypertension: PASP can be estimated at rest and with exercise. Evaluation of mitral valve disease, including MS and MR Aortic stenosis: helpful in patients with low gradient aortic stenosis or asymptomatic aortic stenosis. HCM: Evaluation of LVOT gradients, MR, and pulmonary hypertension.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. - Cardiac MRI to evaluate ventricular scar and aortic valve morphology - It is not the next reasonable step in the given clinical case. It could be done after getting the stress echo findings. Option: B. - Cardiac positron emission tomography to determine ventricular viability - PET scan is not available at many centers and also it is costly and not routinely done in these cases. Option: C. - invasive procedures are not recommended before stress echo - a better noninvasive option.

questions.text: Which of the following physical examination findings are associated with severe aortic stenosis?

options.label: A
options.text: A delayed and weak carotid pulse

options.label: B
options.text: Augmentation of the murmur with Valsalva

options.label: D
options.text: Holosystolic murmur at the apex radiating to the axilla

questions.correct_answer: A. A delayed and weak carotid pulse
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A delayed and weak carotid pulse A delayed and weak carotid pulse is typical in cases of severe aortic stenosis. The carotid arterial pulse rises slowly to a delayed peak (pulsus parvus et tardus). In the late stages, when stroke volume declines the systolic pressure may fall and the pulse pressure will narrow.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Augmentation of the murmur with Valsalva (left ventricular preload reduction) occurs in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with outflow tract obstruction . Option: C. Bounding femoral pulse is commonly felt in aortic regurgitation. Option: D. Describes the murmur of mitral regurgitation

questions.text: Which of the following parameters is typically reduced in chronic severe aortic regurgitation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diastolic blood pressure During diastole, as a large volume of blood leaves the systemic circulation to regurgitate into the LV, the diastolic pressure falls, often equilibrating with the LV pressure in severe cases.

Highyeild:

aortic regurgitation (AR)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: C. An increase in the left ventricle (LV) end-diastolic volume (increased preload) constitutes the major hemodynamic compensation for aortic regurgitation (AR), thus preload is increased. Option: B. The total LV stroke volume also increases to attempt to maintain effective LV stroke volume (total LV stroke volume – regurgitant volume). To do this, the LV must dilate. Option: D. As the LV dilates, the wall tension to develop a given systolic blood pressure must increase as dictated by Laplace’s law, and thus afterload is increased. Coronary perfusion occurs primarily during diastole and depends on the gradient between aortic pressure and LV pressure through the coronaries. This explains why patients with severe AR may manifest anginal symptoms.

questions.text: A 21-year-old with connective tissue disease. presented with acute shortness of breath and a chest x-ray showing diffuse pulmonary edema to cardiac intensive care unit Physical examination revealed a soft, short early diastolic murmur at the right upper sternal border, and emergent echocardiography showed severe aortic regurgitation with an avulsed right coronary cusp. CT chest imaging showed no aortic dissection. On arrival at the cardiac care unit, she is intubated and sedated. Their blood pressure is 110/50 and their heart rate is 115 beats/min. Her urine output is poor and her extremities are cool. The cardiothoracic surgical team is tied up in a heart transplant and will not be able to take this patient for at least 4 more hours. What intervention is most likely to help maintain her end-organ perfusion until surgical intervention?

options.label: A
options.text: Esmolol continuous IV infusion titrated to a heart rate of 60-70 beats/min

questions.explanation:
Solution:

IV nitroprusside This patient has severe, acute aortic regurgitation and indeed warrants emergent surgery. Her murmur is very quiet and short. In the setting of acute, severe valvular regurgitant lesions, the pressure gradient between the two chambers (in this case the aorta and left ventricle) quickly equilibrates during the regurgitant period . In this case, the goal is to reduce the regurgitant volume and thus increase effective stroke volume (total stroke volume – regurgitant volume). Nitroprusside will reduce systemic vascular resistance, and thus reduce the driving pressure for regurgitation. Careful administration of nitroprusside, often with concomitant invasive hemodynamic monitoring, may stabilize organ perfusion and allow surgical correction. It is important to realize that no medical therapy will correct this abnormality—surgical correction is the only definitive therapy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options: A & D . Interventions that increase systemic vascular resistance (vasopressin or norepinephrine) will increase regurgitant volume- and blood outflow will decrease. Option: B . Likewise, since aortic regurgitation occurs during diastole, interventions that increase the diastolic time (e.g., beta-blockers) will also worsen regurgitant volume. Since intra-aortic balloon pumps inflate during diastole, they will also worsen regurgitation from the aortic to the left ventricle and are contraindicated in moderate or worse aortic regurgitation.

questions.text: As a resident on rounds, you heard your consultant discussing whether a patient's mitral regurgitation (MR) is "primary" or "secondary." What is your consultant talking about?

options.label: A
options.text: In primary MR the leaflets/chordae are responsible for abnormal valve function, whereas in secondary MR the valve dysfunction is usually caused by ventricular remodeling.

options.label: B
options.text: Primary MR occurs early (usually before age 18), whereas secondary MR occurs later in life.

options.label: C
options.text: Primary MR occurs only in prime number years, whereas secondary MR can occur in any year.

options.label: D
options.text: Primary MR is due to a congenital valvular abnormality, whereas secondary MR is not.

questions.correct_answer: A. In primary MR the leaflets/chordae are responsible for abnormal valve function, whereas in secondary MR the valve dysfunction is usually caused by ventricular remodeling.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

In primary MR the leaflets/chordae are responsible for abnormal valve function, whereas in secondary MR the valve dysfunction is usually caused by ventricular remodeling. Chronic mitral regurgitation (MR) can result from several disease processes. A distinction should be drawn between primary MR, in which the leaflets and/ or chordae tendineae are primarily responsible for abnormal valve function.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: C. While secondary (functional) MR, in which the leaflets and chordae tendineae are usually normal but the regurgitation is caused by left ventricular remodeling with annular enlargement, papillary muscle displacement, leaflet tethering, or their combination. Options: B, D. Patient assessment, treatment approach, and long-term prognosis differ significantly between primary and secondary MR .

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is true?

options.label: A
options.text: MVP is more common in connective tissue diseases such as Marfan syndrome or Ehlers-Danlos syndrome

options.label: B
options.text: MVP occurs more commonly in men than in women

options.label: C
options.text: The anterior leaflet is usually more affected than the posterior leaflet

options.label: D
options.text: The clinical course of MVP is invariably pathologic and leads to symptoms

questions.correct_answer: A. MVP is more common in connective tissue diseases such as Marfan syndrome or Ehlers-Danlos syndrome
questions.explanation:
Solution:

MVP is more common in connective tissue diseases such as Marfan syndrome or Ehlers-Danlos syndrome In most patients with mitral valve prolapse (MVP), the cause is unknown, but in some, it appears to be genetically determined. A reduction in the production of type III collagen has been incriminated, and electron microscopy has revealed fragmentation of collagen fibrils. MVP is a frequent finding in patients with heritable disorders of connective tissue, including Marfan syndrome, osteogenesis imperfecta, andEhlers-Danloss syndrome.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: C. The posterior mitral leaflet is usually more affected than the anterior, and the mitral valve annulus is often dilated. Option: B. MVP is more common in women and occurs most frequently between the ages of 15 and 30 years; Option: D. the clinical course is most often benign.

questions.text: You are taking care of a 77-year-old patient with severe aortic stenosis in the cardiac intensive care unit. Surgical aortic valve replacement is planned for tomorrow. However, suddenly, he becomes severely short of breath and manifests signs of acute pulmonary edema. On auscultation, you can now appreciate a soft, short apical systolic murmur (in addition to his prior-appreciated murmur of aortic stenosis) that was not present previously. You suspect that he has suffered a ruptured mitral valve chordae and now has severe, acute mitral regurgitation. Which of the following parameters will likely increase due to his new severe mitral regurgitation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ejection fraction Ejection fraction (EF), however, will increase as the LV will be better able to contract in the state of relatively lower afterload. This highlights a misconception that higher EF is “always better.” Left ventricular EF is highly dependent not only on the contractile state of the ventricle but also on its afterload state. This patient is in a precarious situation and likely will require emergent surgical intervention to survive. The combination of severe obstruction to left ventricular (LV) outflow (severe aortic stenosis) and acute, severe regurgitant mitral valve disorder will inevitably lead to intractable pulmonary edema and cardiogenic shock unless both structural abnormalities are corrected.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. The aortic valve gradient will decline merely because there is less volume going across the aortic valve with each contraction. Option: B. Likewise, since both catheter-derived and echocardiographic- derived calculations of aortic valve area are dependent on the gradient for calculation, they will decline . Option: C. Likewise, with more of the stroke volume going ineffectively into the left atrium, the effective stroke volume (total stroke volume – regurgitant volume) will decline .

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to your office for evaluation. She appears healthy and is not limited by physical activity. She says that she has occasional chest pains that occur at rest, often with a change in position. Her blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 76 beats per minute and regular. Auscultatory findings are a mid-systolic click followed by a 2/6 apical systolic murmur that radiates to her axilla. Which of the following dynamic physical examination findings would confirm your suspicion of mitral valve prolapse?

options.label: A
options.text: There is no change in the click with squatting or standing

options.label: B
options.text: A passive leg raise makes the click-murmur occur earlier

options.label: C
options.text: A squat maneuver makes the click-murmur occur later

options.label: D
options.text: The mitral regurgitant murmur does not change with positional maneuvers

questions.correct_answer: C. A squat maneuver makes the click-murmur occur later
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A squat maneuver makes the click-murmur occur later The 30-year-old patient presents with atypical chest pain, which may be associated with mitral valve prolapse. Mitral valve prolapse is essentially a mismatch of the left ventricular cavity size and the mitral valve leaflets, which are redundant.

Highyeild:

MVP murmur MR murmur Valsalva (Ventricle fill less) Longer ↓ Standing Longer ↓ Squatting (Venous filling) Shorter ↑ Supine Shorter ↑ Hand grip ↓ ↑ (↑ Aortic Pressure) As blood is not pushed into aorta ventricle still filled with blood and Chordae tight As ventricles. cant push blood into aorta more blood to Lt. Atrium

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. The classic bedside maneuver is the squat-to-stand maneuver; however, any maneuver that increases the left ventricular cavity size will delay mid-systolic clicks and the mitral regurgitant murmur. Options: B, D. The Valsalva maneuver decreases venous return, which would result in a smaller left ventricle and thus an earlier mitral valve prolapse. A postextrasystolic beat (due to the compensatory pause), the passive leg raise, and the squat (all would improve left ventricular filling) should actually delay mid-systolic clicks and murmur.

The systolic murmur of mitral regurgitation and not due to Mitral valve prolapse is intensified with isometric exercise (handgrip) due to a decrease in preload. Acute severe mitral regurgitation has asymmetric pulmonary edema if the regurgitant jet the directed to the orifice of the upper lobe pulmonary vein Mitral regurgitation: in the above case there is the presence of presystolic murmur in a mitral area with systolic thrill, thus it is the case of mitral regurgitation.
